div1.p: KNAVE, OR NOT? A COMEDY: IN FIVE ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. G. AND J. ROBINSON, PATERNOSTER ROW.

div1.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div1.p:
THE unrelenting opposition which the productions of the author of the present comedy have experienced for several years is well known, to those who pay attention to our public amusements. It is not for him to pronounce how far this opposition has been merited by inability. Since the appearance of The Road to Ruin, his comedy of The Deserted Daughter only has escaped; and that, as he imagines, because it was not known on the night of its first performance by whom it was written. Love's Frailties, The Man of Ten Thousand, and Knave or Not? have sustained increasing marks of hostility: so that the efforts made to afford rational amusement to the public, emolument to the author, and improvement to morals, have been rendered feeble and almost ineffectual. In the last instance, one mistake appears to have pervaded the majority of the spectators. It was imagined that the author himself was as unqualified a libeller of mankind as Monrose: in which character the writer's individual sentiments were supposed to have been incorporated. Those who have read his other works surely cannot attribute to him any such indiscriminate misanthropy. The accusation that has most generally been made against him is that he thinks men capable of gradations of virtue, which others affirm they can never attain. Persons, who have made the human mind their study, have discovered that guilty men exert the whole force of their faculties to justify their own course of action to themselves. To this principle the writer was strictly attentive, in pourtraying the character of Monrose. His design was to draw a man of genius, misled by his passions, reasoning on his actions, systematizing them, condemning them in principle, but justifying them in practice, and heating his imagination by contemplating the crimes of others; that he might still maintain that respect for himself of which the strongest minds, even in the last stages of vice, are so tenacious. How far that spirit of faction, commotion, and anarchy, of which the author has long been and is still so vehemently accused, is to be traced in the present comedy may now be seen. Sincerely desirous of giving no offence, the passages which were most disapproved, or to speak more accurately reprobated, on the first night, have since been omitted in representation: but they are printed between inverted
commas; that the cool judgment may decide whether the author could have been so insane as actually to intend to enflame the spectators, and increase a spirit of enmity between men of different sentiments: whom, could he reconcile, he would account it the most beneficial and heart consoling action of his life. The seventh scene in the fourth act is likewise omitted, in the performance: because, instead of giving pleasure, it appeared tedious. It is inserted here rather to preserve a necessary connection between the scenes, than to appeal from the judgment and the feelings of a whole audience.

Before the comedy appeared, all parties were anxious that no sentence or word should be spoken, which could be liable to misrepresentation. Some few passages, therefore, are committed to the press, which never were spoken on the Stage: particularly the concluding part of the last speech in the second act, where Monrose enquires into his qualifications for being a lord. A few years ago, this would have been common-place satire: and it is a subject of no little regret that, at present, local and temporary applications are so liable to be made where none are intended.

Truth requires it should be mentioned that, in the original sketch of this comedy, some hints were taken from IL RAGGIRATORE, LA SERVA AMOROSA, and IL PADRE DI FAMIGLIA, by GOLDONI: but of these, though he has not lately examined them, the author is persuaded so few traces remain that they are scarcely discoverable. They are mentioned, because he considers the least concealment of such a kind as derogatory to that veracity which it is the peculiar duty of moral writers to inculcate.

lg.l: AMONG the various ways by wit devis'd,
To paint our faults and follies, undisguis'd,
Through every age is found of most avail
The well drawn character, and well told tale.
Hence has the Stage become the last resort
Of injured Innocence: her proper court.
"The guilty wretch," whom power and gold can screen,
"Struck to the soul," will sicken at the scene.
Vice that, with front erect and brazen eye,
In broad day pomp will pass unblushing by,
Should he be seen but "sitting at a play,"
How will his secret sins that conscious eye betray!
Pert Folly too, caprice in every freak,
Displays her feather'd head, and painted cheek;
While, "louder far than Wisdom in the street,"
She cries—"Lo! Here am I! Come, worship at my feet!"
The thoughtless crowd, thus summon'd to adore her,
Hear, stare, obey, and prostrate fall before her.
Yet let her be in all her frippery caught,
Just as she shews herself, and hither brought,
The moment here she's seen the witless elves
Laugh at their goddess, and despise—themselves.
Fantastic changeling! Catch her? Ay! But how?
Th' attempt is bending great Ulysses' bow!
And yet again we come, with random darts;
Now aiming at your heads, now at your hearts:
But all in mirth, and with no ill intent;
At Vice and Folly our few shafts are sent:
We shoot but o'er the house, or in the dark;
Hoping that you'll be pleas'd, whene'er we hit the mark.

div1.head: EPILOGUE.
div1.byline: BY M. G. LEWIS, ESQ. M. P. AUTHOR OF THE MONK, THE CASTLE SPECTRE, &C.

lg.l: I AM angry!—Quite angry!—The whole of this night
I've been ready to burst with vexation and spite;
And now am come hither in haste, to disclose
Why grief swells my bosom, and reddens my nose!
In hopes a new road to your favour to find,
The mask of Thalia I lately resigned;
And, undaunted by prejudice, fashion, or scandal,
Melpomene's dagger I ventured to handle.
My heroic exertions, the truth to confess,
By the Public's indulgence were crowned with success;
For, when with distraction my bosom was seized,
I'm sure, you all seemed to be mightily pleased;
When my poniard I drew, you applauded the action;
And, whenever I murdered, showed great satisfaction.
Then is it not hard, that our Author to-night
Should have dragged me at once from my tragical height▪
My Bristol-stone dagger away has he ta'en;
He has cut off four yards of my white satin train,
And presumptuously begs, for the rest of the season,
That I'd try to amuse you with nature and reason!
This prayer, I protested, I never could grant;
I had ranted and raved, and would still rave and rant;
And I told him, this part, which for me he had planned,
Was not half enough furious, terrific, or grand.
I see not one Ghost through the whole of the part;
Cannot once find a place for a Tragedy start:
My bosom I beat not; my locks must not rend;
Nor murder one man from beginning to end!
My displeasure and anger resolved to display,
I called at the door of our Author, one day;
Was admitted—sat down—cleared my voice—furled my fan—
Put my critical face on, and gravely began.
Says I—"Mr. Thingummy, plainly to speak,
"Your hold on the public opinion is weak;
"For your canvas presents neither Daemons nor Witches▪
"And your Villains appear in coat, waistcoat, and breeches!
"Now let me advise you your subject to change,
"For something that's showy, terrific, and strange.
"That his Play must succeed, may the Bard safely boast,
"Who opens the piece with a Song by a Ghost;
"But in popular plaudits unbounded he revels,
"If he follows the Song with a Dance by two Devils.
"Observe too, you'll greatly increase the effect,
"If your colours with caution and taste you select:
"Thus, to make on the feelings a serious attack,
"Let your Spectres be white, and your Servants be black;
"And, to finish the whole with a striking new Scene,
"Let a Pompadour Prince wed a Coquelicot Queen.
"Give us Lightning and Thunder, Flames, Daggers and Rage;
"With events that ne'er happened, except on the Stage:
"When your Spectre departs, through a trap-door ingulph her,
"Burn under her nose too some brimstone and sulphur;
"Let Magicians and Monsters be poured on our view;
"And stick on your Villains a beard of pale blue Alluding to the Romance of Blue-Beard.!"
My remonstrance was vain—He asserts, you can be
Well-pleased, when good-sense, mirth, and nature you see,
Though his Play should not leave you half dead with affright:
And I heartily pray, that the man may be right.
As for me (though I'm sorry, my part won't permit
Me to squall at a Spectre, and frighten the Pit),
I hope you'll allow this performance has merit,
And though without Ghost, think 'tis not without spirit;
Which Spirit on Monday, escaping from Styx,
Will appear in this place—at a quarter past six.

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: THY argufying, Harry, is all nonsense. Don't I know that I am Susan Monrose, the poor curate of Finchcliffe's daughter; and that thee beest my brother?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Pshaw! You are a simpleton.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay, ay: mayhap I may. But I won't be wicked: so don't tempt me to pertend that thee beest an outlandish lord, when I know thee to be nobody but Harry Monrose.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Be quiet; and listen to what I have to say. I have always loved you, Susan.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Well, Harry, thee canno' deny but there's no love lost.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Though your education has been neglected, you are a charming girl. 'Twere a shame that so much beauty and intelligence should be buried in obscurity. I am determined to make your fortune, and my own.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Not by becoming a wicked cheat! No, Harry, that's not the way.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You mistake: that is the only way. "'Tis the common calling! For gowns, gold chains, and white wands are its rewards." From high to low 'tis all bargain and sale. And what is bargain and sale? Why to display the good side, and conceal the bad: that is, to cheat and lie!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Oh Harry, Harry! Is all the learning father bestowed on thee come to this? He said, when thee run away, how it would be.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I have travelled, know the world, and mean to profit by my knowledge. Fools and knaves are the two grand classes: for the honest men are too insignificant, and too few, to form a class. Poverty and disgrace are got by keeping them company; and he that would thrive must shun them, as he would the plague.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Surely, Harry, thee canno' be in downright earnest?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Such is the world: and shall I, like a driveller, make myself its football? No; it shall be mine! And I will spurn▪ it before me with the contempt it deserves! While I despise and laugh at its prejudices, I will profit by them.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Look thee, Harry, I canno' tell why thee beest so bitter angry wi' the world. I can truly vouch I have met wi' many good folk, and few bad. And as to go for to say that thee beest a lord, I'll do no such thing!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aside) I must deceive the obstinate fool, for her own advantage—You mistake the matter. Once again, I tell you, I am a lord.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Oh for shame, Harry! Don't I know that to be an un possable thing?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why! As if they could make a lord out of thee! Whereof a lord is a great—unspeakable—Grandee!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! But I am a foreign Count. Any man may be created a Count, abroad.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Created a Count? Oh, what blasphemy! But what dost tell me about Counts, and lords? Here beest thee a kind of a school-master, to young Mr. Jonas: which be a dessunt modest calling enough; but not fit for a lord! It be a deuced puzzleation thing to learn to read, and spell, and put together; and I be very sure a downright lord would never take the trouble.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well but, answer me: would it not rejoice your heart to be a lady?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What sort of a lady? There be your lady such as I saw go on a visitation to the King's birthday; and there be the Taylor's lady, that lives in the alley and sells red herrings.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: How acute you are, hussey! Follow my advice and you shall soon be a real lady.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What and ride in my coach?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, girl.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Keep two footmen, a parrot, a lap-dog, and a monkey?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh a whole menagerie of monkies.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Wear high feathers, long gowns, short petticoats, red slippers, and clock stockings?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: If you please.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Have my bed warmed every night, lie as long as I like of a morning, eat buttered crumpets for breakfast, plumb dumplings for dinner, and oranges and sweetmeats for luncheon and supper?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Served up with sugar-candy sauce. Ha, ha, ha! Should you like it?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Like it? How am I to get it?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: By getting a rich husband.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What one of your London Squire Jemmies; with his thing'embobs down to his ancles, his hands in his pockets, his switch in his boot, his impudent stare, and his hop skip and swagger "How do you do, my dear?"

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! By my soul, Susan, thou art a jewel of a girl. I am enraptured with thy spirit of observation.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why look thee, brother Harry, if it be thy meaning that I should lend thee my little finger here toward the cheating of other people, thou'll be plaguily cheated thysel': so take warning. No, Harry, I love thee too well to turn my hand to tricks that shall bring thee to shame.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aside) Infatuated little fool! But I have her safe.—I find, Susan, I have been mistaken. I thought you had a kind of a liking for my young pupil? Hay? Nay, speak.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Who dost mean?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Come, come, sister, no hypocrisy!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: May hap, Harry, thee beest joking me on account of young Mr. Jonas?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Indeed I am very serious. What if he should offer you marriage?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, brother Harry, an' if he should make me such an offer, where would be the harm? Mr. Jonas be well enough to see to: and, thof he be a bit oafish and skittish, yet, i'the main, a's good conditioned.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: That is, you like him?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No, Harry, it is no' come to that yet: 'cause why a's of rich parentage, and I of poor; whereby thee mayst take it for sartin, Harry, that I know how to keep my thoughts to mysel'. So I think nought about him.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Reason enough. 'Tis little likely 'at his kinsfolk should gi' consent.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Fear nothing: they shall! I have the means.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay, marry! What be they?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Their own misdeeds. He that would make the rich his tool must worm out their secret vices: he then has them in his gripe, and the tyrant becomes the slave.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Harry, Harry, I do hugeously doubt thee beest becoming a reprobate!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Do not mistake me, girl. I love not mischief for its own sake: I act but on the defensive, and turn the weapons of oppression against itself. My whole plan is this: I sent for you up to town purposely to marry this headlong youth; who, if he has not the good fortune to have you, will make some cookmaid or kept mistress his wife. I have lodged you here a few weeks to teach you a little of the town manner; and have brought Jonas to see you, who is mad after every woman he meets. To day I will introduce you to his mother, Lady Ferment. Prepare yourself, and act and speak according to my instructions.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Sulkily) It signifies nothing talking, Harry: I'll do nought but that which is upright, and downright.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Angrily) Zounds, girl, have done with this absurd stuff. I know what is right, you do not. If fair and direct means cannot succeed, who is to blame? Neither you nor I. Once more, obey my directions. Great events are on the eve of disclosure. Should you traverse and betray me, I will never own you for a sister more. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why then I wunno' be consarned i' wickedness, Harry, do what thee wo't! No! I wunno'! I wunno'! (Ready to cry.) I do love thee dearly: wi' aw my heart and soul: and I would no' see thee come to disgrace no not to be the Queen of England! So dunno' thee expect it o' me—But then a says and declares there be no wickedness i' the case. May hap there be not. I hope there be not! I do hope there be not!—As to Mr. Jonas, a' be a likely lad to look to. That there be no denying: A be plaguy rumbustical to be sure: but, an it should be our good hap to wed, I guess a'd be cured o' that—I do find mysel' in a strange quandary. I be as good flesh and blood mayhap as he. I be a woman, and he be but a mon. Yea, belemmy, we be aw Adam's children: but silks and satins make the difference. [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE III.— Changes to the House of SIR JOB.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Upon my soul, Miss Aurelia, it is true. I think I never saw a neater turned ancle! And for a white arm, and a fine fall of the neck, there is nobody like you!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I am surprised to hear all these gallant things from you, Mr. Jonas; when you yesterday confessed you were in love with your tutor's sister.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What, Miss Susan? So I was. But she is like the rest of you: if I offer to touch her, she sets up her back, and darts her sharp little fangs, just like the cat at the mastiff.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Is she a prude?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I don't know what you call prude, but I know she won't let me come at her.—You are my mother's companion.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ay. Heigho! Happy girl!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: But I have been thinking—

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You had better by half be mine.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What does my mother want with a dear delicious—now I do.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Why you are absolutely a rake, Mr. Jonas.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: A rake? No. I'll marry you.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! What would Lady Ferment say?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What care I what she says?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Indeed you are a sad rake! You are so fond of the ladies!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: How can I help it? I wish they were as fond of me! Ecod there would be rare work.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You make love to them all.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No: there's one exception.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: My mother. She makes love to me.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: And you treat her as you say the cat does the mastiff.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Serve her right. She should not be so fond, and foolish.

sp.speaker: LADY FERMENT.
sp.p: (Without. Calis) Jonas!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Tch! Tch! Tch! Here she comes. Will you consent?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I can't.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I dare not venture on such a seducer.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ah! You have an eye somewhere else.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Pooh!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Yes, you have.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Jonas, dear, what are you doing?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Not what I like.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Aurelia, child, take care of yourself! This pet boy is becoming a sad tempter!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: A very dangerous one indeed, my lady.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: That's a fib, now.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are, child. I am sure you are; and it becomes young women not to trust themselves alone with you.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ecod, you need not teach them that: they won't.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I have been telling him what a seducer he is.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nonsense. I am not.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are, Jonas, dear.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ay, indeed are you! I must beware of you, Mr. Jonas.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nah! You are all alike; with your flings and fleers.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: 'Twas lucky that my lady came!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ya, ya, ya! Ecod I'll go and kill the parrot, set the cat at the lap-dog, and give both your muffs to the monkey! [Exit.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Sweet boy!—I am glad, my dear, you see your danger. Your situation, child, is a perilous one.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Yes, yes, my lady, I am fully aware of my situation.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Come with me: I want to consult you on a new dress. You have a very tolerable taste, in putting on your things; and that is a great requisite, in a dependent young woman. That and prudence, with a cautious tongue! Hear, see, and say nothing, is the waiting-woman's duty.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Waiting-woman, my Lady!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I don't mean you, child. You are something above that: you are my companion.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: It is a new calling: your Ladyship must be kind enough to instruct me.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I will, I will. Come with me: I will.

div3.head: SCENE VI. Enter MONROSE, and MRS. CLACK.

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: So, as I tell you, Sir Count, I am no tattler. I don't go blabbing to this person, and chattering to that. I have no gossiping acquaintance to babble all my secrets to. I have put a lock upon my lips. I don't know how I came to make so free with you! But you have such a 'sinuating way! However, you are as close as myself. Beside, though you are down in the world, you are a gentleman, Sir Count; and, if I tell you any thing, it is as safe as in my own bosom.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You need not doubt of that.

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Oh, I know it! I know it!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, and so—?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: And so, if what I am going to tell you of Sir Job and Mr. Taunton should ever be known, I believe in my conscience it would bring them to—dear! dear!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: That's my notion of the matter. But there is no danger that you should blab.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You know me too well.

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: I do! I do! And so, I will tell you. Miss Aurelia is Mr. Taunton's distant relation. She was his first wife's sister's child.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You amaze me!

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: To my certain knowledge! And, what is more, she is, as I have heard a small bird sing, the rightful heiress to a mortal deal of money.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Aha!

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: And, though nobody dare for the soul of them say so much, it's a crying sin she should be cheated, as she is, and robbed of her due.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Is it then known?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Oh, no! except to—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Why, that—that is another secret.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nay but, my dear Mrs. Clack, you are very well convinced you may trust me.

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: I have trusted you with my master's secret; but this is my own. It concerns my own character; and if, at my age, I should lose that—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Can you think I would take away the character of my friend; who has generously opened her whole heart to me?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: It would be a base action in you, if you did! What can be more wicked than to tell a circumstance that should ruin one's reputation; after one has escaped so many traps, and snares, with as fair an outside as any woman in the parish?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: And could I, think you, be so wicked?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: I have lived in this family many years: in which time, as you may suppose, a number of chance accidents have happened: and if Mr. Quake—that is—Bless me! what am I saying?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Who is Mr. Quake?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Nobody: nobody at all. I was raving, I believe!—Miss Aurelia was charitably educated by an old lady, who—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You have told me that before. Who is Mr. Quake?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Why the whole blame does not lie on Mr. Taunton: Sir Job was the other executor.

sp.speaker: MON▪
sp.p: Pshaw! I know it. Who is Mr. Quake?

sp.speaker: MRS. C.
sp.p: Why Mr. Quake—Bless me! I am so flurried!—Hush! Somebody is coming! It is my master! Don't notice me. Why, Betty! Why don't you come? [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A word, if you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I am come to tell you, Sir, that I don't approve your proceedings.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am sorry for that, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A fig for sorrow, Sir. I will be master of my own premises!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Who so proper?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What right had you to bring this Miss Aurelia into my doors?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aside) Oh ho!—Lady Ferment wanted a companion.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Don't companion me, Sir! You come here a stranger, you give yourself out for a foreign Count, you are received into my family as a tutor, and before you have been three months you cajole my Lady, controul me, and introduce your madams as my inmates.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Moderate your anger, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Sir, I will be as angry as I please. I am in my own house, Sir. A'n't I, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Do you doubt it, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes, I do doubt it, Sir. No, I don't doubt it, Sir. What do you mean by doubt it, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Was Aurelia Roland then a total stranger to you, Sir Job?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Sir!—What—What do you mean by that question?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Did you never hear her name mentioned?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I, Sir!—When?—What?—Where must I hear?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Are you wholly unacquainted with her family?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Sir, I—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why should the question alarm you, Sir Job?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A—a—a—alarm!—What do you mean by alarm?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: The Rolands, I am told, were formerly wealthy?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What—What is that to me?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: It is possible you might have heard of such a thing.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Sir, I am—I do—I don't understand.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aside) The old shark! But I'll give him line for the present.—She is a charming handsome girl.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What of that, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I know you love my Lady: Yet the most loving husbands are sometimes caught tripping.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Hay? What?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: A city knight and alderman might have a partiality for so fine a young creature.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p:
Oh! Is that it? Ha, ha, ha! What,
you suspected—hay?—Ha, ha, ha! That is very good! I perceive, Count, you are a wag. Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! Heigho!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, well, if any secrets should have passed between you, and I can be of service—You comprehend me?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Hay? What secrets? How?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Any amorous follies.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh!—No. Ha, ha, ha! By my knighthood, never.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Then you don't know Aurelia?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Know? I—How—Where should I—Hay?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: If so, I have been misinformed.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: How! Informed? Bless me! I—Who?—Informed?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Come, come, don't deny it, Sir Job. You know more than you like to confess.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No—no—n n no, I don't.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, you do.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, indeed; upon my veracity!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, well, Sir Job, you have lived long enough in the world to know its maxims. If you stand in need of any man, you are wise and will make it that man's interest to be your friend. "You are an alderman, and a magistrate, and set a proper value on a smug wig, a smooth chin, and a shining pair of shoes. You have learnt the trick on't; and know that justice consists in keeping gravity on the countenance, and money in the pocket. Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha!" [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Mercy on me! What a tremble I am in! What does he mean? He half talks as if he knew Aurelia Ro—

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What's the matter with you, Sir Job?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nothing! Nothing, Sir Guy.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Zounds! You are in an ague! How pale you are!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A little qualm. It will go off.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Where's your son?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What Jonas?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, your other son; the neglected Oliver.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I don't know. There's no peace in the house for him. Pays my Lady no respect.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Much more than she deserves.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Plays the very devil!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You mistake: that is her part.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: She? Oh no! Good creature! She's all my comfort.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Then God help you.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: So tender! So loving!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: That her first husband hanged himself.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ah! He was a foolish man. I know how to manage her.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And she knows how to manage you.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh, we are well paired! I wish you had such a wife!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The devil you do!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Such cordiality between us! Not but, if my Lady's nerves were not so weak, I should often fall in a passion.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You should?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh! I am plaguy hot, at times! Do you know, I am chosen Colonel of the What do you call it Associates?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p:
Ay, am I! Why I am a man of war by
birth-right. My father was army hatter, and famous for inventing the Cumberland cock!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Tremendous!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And I myself was once a contractor for accoutrements, grenadiers' caps, cartouch boxes, bullets, and buff belts. Nay, I have since dealt in gunpowder.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is that you talk about gunpowder▪ Sir Job? 'Tis unmannerly to mention such things before ladies.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, he never does when your Ladyship is present.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh no! Never!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My deary is always kind. (To a Servant) Go, man, and prepare your master's chocolate. [Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ah! My lovy is ever thinking of me! Sir Guy called, chucky, to enquire after your health. He heard you had got a cold at the masquerade, and was so sorry! Was not you? Has been saying the civilest things of you! Have not you?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Infinitely obliged to Sir Guy. Will you take a cup of chocolate, Sir, with my deary?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh no. I have just had a glass of bitters.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: They are very good for the stomach.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And Sir Job knows your Ladyship is excellent at preparing them.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I'll match her for that with any wife in ten parishes.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Deary always thinks too well of me. Did you take your new-laid egg, sweet, this morning?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Surely I did! Lovy gave it me herself, with her own fair hand.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I have ordered your jelly at two.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ah, precious!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your glass of Cyprus wine and a biscuit at four.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Kind lambkin!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And some turtle soup before dinner.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (To Sir Guy) Do you hear?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are become a military man, Sir Job, and require a strengthening diet.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Very true. Ods thunder! Sweety will make a Sampson of me!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A Sampson!—Well, and how does your son Oliver, my Lady?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My son, indeed! He is no son of mine.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: He is the son of your husband; therefore yours.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Ay, indeed!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Unquestionably: if you have any regard to your character.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Who would dare to impeach my character?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I should. Every body would.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: For a baronet and a man of breeding, Sir, you have a very strange way with you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I know it. 'Tis some people's failing to tell lies: 'tis mine to tell truth. But pray what are Oliver's faults?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A thousand, Sir!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Name one.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I name?—Ask his own father.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay, let us hear. Come, begin▪

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why don't you speak, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Terrified) My dear!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You have no pity on my poor nerves▪

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes, I have, lovy.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Count over your graceless son's pranks. Have you lost your tongue, man?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, no, deary: but you know my memory begins to fail.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My poor tender frame! Proceed, Sir Job, and don't shew yourself a savage! Paint your son in his true colours.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I will, I will! First he is a tall, wellmade, handsome—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Handsome?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, no! Ugly: a sort of ugly fellow.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Well said, knight!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Has a bold, open, manly—Hem!—Insolent air. Feeds like a hungry German at a table d'hôte, and refuses to dine with the servants.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh the proud villain!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Aspires to keep the best company.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: The worst company: and, to maintain his extravagance, has audaciously petitioned for a hundred a year pocket money.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Of a father who has only a rent roll of three thousand per annum, and a plumb and a half in the funds.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Very little more!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oliver is acquainted with your affairs▪ and methinks he might be very useful.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What's true, Sir Job? Have not you renounced trade?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: But not closed his accounts.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, my Lady: you know, I have not closed my accounts.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why will you dare, Sir Job, to talk in this style, and look me in the face?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No, no, my Lady! Not and look you in the face.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why, knight, I think it is my Lady that deals in gun powder?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I see how it is! My nervous frame is not to be spared! I am to be thrown into a fit!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, my Lady!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why Sampson!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Her sit is coming!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Let it. I'll burn the feathers, and sprinkle the water.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I am surprised, Sir Guy, at your behaviour.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Likely enough: for I am surprised at yours.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are a strange person.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay▪ many people tell me so. But I hear you have a young lady come to be your companion, of whom Oliver relates wonders.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oliver is a forward blockhead. Deary, I am sure, won't like her long.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I am sure to the contrary, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay, truly! I am glad to hear that.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: She is a tasty person; just what I wanted. I have sent her to my milliner's; and on a few errands.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: On errands?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: One must treat these kind of people properly at first, or they grow familiar.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: If she possess the rare qualities Oliver describes, your Ladyship I guess will soon have her at a very proper distance.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: The greater the better.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: She came recommended by your English foreign tutor?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: By Count Monrose, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! ay: Count. I beg his Countship's pardon.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: He is a gentleman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: So is every sharper about town.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A man who returned to England loaded with honors.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It was all the baggage he had.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You have a licentious tongue, Sir Guy.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I know it. It is my plague; and it is a worse plague to others than it is to myself. I warn your Ladyship to beware of it, and treat Oliver like your son; or I foresee it will be busy. It is the more dangerous too because it deals in mere matter of fact. What it relates is credited; for I am notoriously a stupid fellow, without a grain of invention. I came purposely to tell you this, in a friendly way. Sir Job, remember your new occupation. Think how you once dealt in grenadier's caps, cartouch boxes, bullets, and buff belts. Be a man of war: my Lady will love you the better.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Half aside) Impertinent person.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay, lovy.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Begone, iron-hearted wretch!

div3.head: SCENE I. The Terrace of the House of SIR GUY, at a Village near London.
div3.stage: SIR GUY and MR. TAUNTON coming from the Shrubbery.

sp.speaker: MR. TAUNTON.
sp.p: NAY but why are you so pettish?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Because I like it.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: An angry man, brother, rides a runaway horse. Here have you every thing that heart could wish.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, I have not.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To be rid of you.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Don't be so waspish, brother.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I will, drone.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Pray let me advise you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Do, that I may laugh at you.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Be considerate, be smooth. You are all fire and flash.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) And you are all frost and fool.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: From the wise meek replies.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: From jackdaws foolish saws.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Nay but give me a reason?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Give you brains, you mean.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Why are you so snappish?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: For the good of my health.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I don't understand you!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Who said you did?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: How is your health concerned?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Would you have me, like yourself, a composition of cheese curd and cucumber, tie myself up in a money-bag, imprison my soul in the
circumference of a guinea, sink to inanity with hearing it chink, and crawl to my grave like a pullet dying of the pip?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Neglect a penny, and squander a pound.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Pshaw! An ass is a dull animal. "Put nutmeg in your drink, eat mustard, and mend."

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Patience is a good pilot.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You have less brains, less life, less propagation in you, than a Cheshire cheese: for that will at least breed maggots: but a miser begins and ends with himself. I wonder who the devil made you my brother! Give me a fellow that has mischief in his marrow.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Well but about this young woman, that you were talking of: you surely must be mistaken!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You surely must be a mule.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Her name cannot be Roland?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What impossibility has your wisdom discovered?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Sir Job would not take Aurelia Roland as a companion to his lady!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Because—Hem!—I don't know why.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No? You look as if you did.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Sir Job has sons.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What then? Why is Aurelia Roland more dangerous to his sons than any other woman?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: You just told me how Oliver praised her. But I am sure it cannot be Aurelia Roland.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And how the devil came you so sure?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Have you seen her?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Aside) Aurelia Roland? Impossible! And yet—Well, brother, I must bid you good day.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It will be the better when you are gone.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Patience is a jewel for a prince▪

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Patience is a preaching puppy.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Don't go to market to buy vexation.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I need not go to market, I can have it brought home to me.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Don't burn your house to frighten away the rats. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Zounds and fire! This fellow would proverb a man to death in a fortnight.

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Stay where you are, good woman.—Where is Sir Guy? As cross but as kind hearted an old gentleman as ever breathed! He threatens the poor, as if he were their scourge: but he always relieves and feels for them, like the tenderest of fathers.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what do you want?

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Here's another pauper brought before your worship.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And how comes that? Did not I appoint you my clerk purposely to terrify the neighbourhood and drive away beggars?

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: And ordered me never to pass paupers from the parish without acquainting you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why what the devil, sellow, would you have me send them away by cartloads, sick or well, and suffer them to die on the road; as is the practice in other scoundrel parishes? Who is it?

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: A poor woman with five small children.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh Lord! Thus it is when beggarly boys and girls couple and propagate ploughmen, and weavers, and the riff-raff of the land; who all conspire together to maintain such clever fellows as myself in state!—Send her here!

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: (At the door) Come this way, good woman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: How do you know she is a good woman? Is not she poor? I'll teach her better tricks, I warrant me!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Now, mistress! What business have you to be poor? Don't you know what a crime it is? Have you no husband?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: I had, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What, he is run away, I suppose?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: (With her apron to her eyes) He is dead, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (During this scene, under the shew of anger, he repeatedly stifles his tears) Lord, Lord!—What business had he to die? And so you have five children?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Eight in all, Sir: five young ones at home.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Here's pretty doings! Here's impudence! Breeding of vermin at this rate, to people cabbins and commons, and multiply over moors and mountains! So that, if it were not for that politic purgative, gunpowder, by and by we should not have an acre of waste land left! Are you aware of your wickedness?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: I hope in time, Sir, they will all learn to work.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, oh! What you mean to insinuate that they will grow and come to be good for something?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: If they don't first starve, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
(Tears) Starve! To be sure! What can they expect? Here's flying in the face of authority!
Where's the beadle? Pack her away!

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: (Looking at Sir Guy) I don't think you mean it, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The devil you don't! Why this is worse and worse! (Examining her face) When had you a good meal?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: (Energetically) Never, since my husband's death.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Tears) Here's impertinence! (Again more stedfastly examining) When did you eat last?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Not these two days.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Tears: affecting great anger) Damn me but this is insufferable!—I'll teach you! Take her away!

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Where, your Worship?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To the pantry, you damned villain! To the pantry!

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: (Drily) Must I pass her to her parish?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Do! Do! And I'll pass you to the devil! Give her food; go home with her; examine, dive into wretchedness, and harden your heart, scoundrel; and then give me a full and true account, that I may learn to harden mine. And do you hear, you vile hussey! Let me catch you fasting two days again, if you dare! Let me! That's all! In the mean time take this. (Gives money)

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: The prayers and blessings of the poor be your reward, Sir. [Exeunt Scribe and Woman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Damn me but it is very unaccountable! This woman I suspect has feelings! And sensations! And thoughts! Nay I doubt whether she have not
a heart, and a sort of a soul; and yet she is a pauper!

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Here is a person in the parlour who desires to know if he may be permitted to speak a word with you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A person? A prig you mean.

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: Why so, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: By the impertinence and absurdity of his message. What mighty maggot am I, that a man is to ask permission to speak to me?

sp.speaker: SCR.
sp.p: You are so cross and so kind, Sir!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Zounds! Sir, how can I help it, if my heart be made of such vile pitiful melting materials, that it is overflowing at every instant; and I have no way of shutting and stopping up the flood gates of passion, but by being a crabbed, cankered, damned choleric scoundrel? [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE VI. The House of SIR JOB.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: You are a witness of the humble demeanor I am obliged to wear in my father's house. I am the son of Sir Job by a first wife. He was then poor, and I am told I have no claim upon his present wealth; but that gratitude and crouching are due for the favour of not turning me out of doors.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: It appears you feel your wrongs, but that you submit to them.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: My father aids to inflict them unwillingly, and promises ultimate justice.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: It is for your brother Jonas' sake that you are thus treated.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Not with his intention. He has the caprice and obstinacy of a pampered son, but his heart is open and kind.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: This impartiality is to your honor.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Our parents and seniors are in possession of their property, and the law tells them they have a right to dispose of that as they please; but the hearts and affections of the young are not in their keeping.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but every day's experience proves the contrary.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Can the cold and palsied hand of age tie the delicate knot of love?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: No: but, cold and palsied as it is, it can weave the inevitable web of misery.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Ardently) Be it so! Let me perish, so that I expire on the bosom of the woman I adore!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: And is there such a woman?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: There is.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Will you not tell her name?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Yes, when I can persuade myself she can sympathise with the strong and throbbing emotions of my heart.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Heigho! Let us talk of the weather.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What are your thoughts on marriage?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Thoughts! It is a subject on which a pennyless damsel must not cast a thought.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: But if thoughts will intrude?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Why then thoughts are very impertinent things.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Visitors which cannot be got rid of. Therefore what do you think of matrimony?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p:
That it is the paradise of pleasure for a
few months, and the cave of despair for the remainder of life.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: It is the cradle of love.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Say the tomb: and, love being dead, jealousy, anger, ambition and avarice, all have full play.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What if love were vigorous enough to repel these ravagers?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: He then falls a victim to the petty warfare of caprice, dullness, and the desire of novelty.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What if beauty and wit be his guards?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Alackaday! They are guards that always desert their post; and when on it are so intoxicated with self-admiration that they never do their duty.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: It seems, they are dangerous companions.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let you and I beware of them.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I hope you do not follow the advice you give?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: If I do not follow, it will drive me.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: To—Pshaw! From this house. No, no; I don't know what I say! I shall be driven away by the arrogance of Lady Ferment, which my education does not fit me to endure.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Taking her hand) Then you are a stranger to love?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Fie! Have done! We are two outcasts; but not I presume the outcasts of virtue. Her commands we must obey; and those irrevocable commands are to fly the danger we cannot face.

div3.head: SCENE VII. Enter JONAS with a paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: So, so, brother Nol! These are your tricks! It's my belief you are a sad dog among the girls.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: And what are you, Jonas?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Me? Lord! I am nobody! They only laugh at me! But I'll begin a new course! I'll be a sad dog myself soon! You must know, I am confoundedly in love.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Whom? Why with them all! And it's damned vexatious that I can't get one of them.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Jonas, beware: there is danger in your eagerness. Take a brother's advice, and don't indulge your appetites at the expence of your happiness. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, pupil, have you finished your theme?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh yes, I have finished my theme; and a rare theme it is! All of my own invention!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am glad of that; it is a mark of improvement.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh I shall improve apace, with your help.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, and what is the subject?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What is that to you?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nay you must shew it me.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Must! When?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You should write nothing without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am your governor.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Who told you so?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Come, come, we will not contend for trifles. I am your friend, which is better. Let me see what you have written?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You'll shew it Sir Job?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I will not indeed.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Honor?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Depend upon me.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nay I don't much care if you do. My mother rules the roast, and I rule my mother.—I told you I had an inkling to Miss Susan.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, but—

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: None of your buts, or I'll play you a trick. I like her. She's no fool, and can't chuse but like me. So I have been inditing.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: A love-letter?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I did it off-hand, at a smack. You shall hear. (Reads)

My dear sweet Miss,
I am tired of being snubbed and snapped and crossed and contradicted by my father: for, though not so old, I am as tall as he. I don't like my mother a bit better; so I suppose you like your father and mother as little as I do mine: wherefore I have a proposal to make. I hate slavery; so if you'll take heart we'll be married, that we may both be free. The thought came into my head last night when you and I and the Count were at tea; so I had a mind to have told you just when I gave your knee two or three nudges, which did but make me think of it ten times the more: which is all at present.
Your loving friend till death,
JONAS FERMENT.
Nota bene. An answer by the bearer is expected.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! An original composition.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Will it do?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You come to the point.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why not? I want to be my own master: so I want a wife, that I may be master of somebody else.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: But you have said not a word of that.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, when once we are married, she'll hear it soon enough.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My dear Jonas, have not you finished your morning studies yet?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Yes. I have just done.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I make it a particular request, Count, that you will not indulge the poor boy in severe application.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh leave that to me, mother.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why do you always call me mother, dear?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why a'n't you my mother?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Yes, my sweet boy! But mamma is more affectionate.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Very well, mamma. (Mocking)

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Or, now and then, madam.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I'll take care, madam.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And sometimes your ladyship, or my lady.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh to be sure, your ladyship, my lady.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Ah you are a saucy dear child.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Harkye, my lady your ladyship.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What do you say, bold face?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: If I must not call you mother, don't call me child.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Hear him, Count! Dear impudent pet!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No, I'm too bashful by half; which makes the girls all giggle so at me.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Ah! Let me kiss you, brazen face.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No, you shan't: I am a man, and I'll kiss somebody else.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why, saucebox!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: So I'll—I'll have a wife.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A wife?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Yes, I will; and since you won't look out for me, I have been looking out for myself.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Mercy! Jonas!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I tell you, I have.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: A pretty girl.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Why, child!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I tell you, I am no child: I am a man, and I'll have her.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My dear Jonas, have pity on your poor mamma, and tell me who it is?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: The Count's sister.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Miss Monrose?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Her neck is as white as the driven snow!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: When have you seen her, child?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, I have seen her often enough.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Count!—She is poor.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I like her the better.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Had you paid your addresses to a city heiress, indeed! Beside, you forget, child, you are to go on your travels.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What of that? She may go on her travels too. We shall have a young Jonas, and it will be a fine opportunity for him to see the world, like other travellers, before his eyes are open.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Oh! you dear, witty, wicked darling.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I have opened my mind to her.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: The right straight forward way, to be sure; by letter.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Indeed! Count? And what answer have you received?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What do you mean by an answer, you silly woman? I have not sent it yet. What answer should I receive? She wants a husband, does not she? Beside, a'n't I as rich as—as—as a silversmith's shop, or a banker's money-shovel? Which is just what I want first—so give me some.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Some what, child?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Cash. The ready.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You emptied my purse only yesterday.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What of that? I'll empty it again today.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Nay, my sweet boy, you are too extravagant.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I want a wife and money. You must furnish the last, that I may furnish myself with the first.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Pray, dear Jonas, spare me.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Come, come; give me the rhino, or, look you, I'll begin.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Begin what?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: To swear.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Mercy, child!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I will, like ten troopers!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, don't terrify me!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Give me the shiners then.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I must not.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Then I'll swear away.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I shall faint.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Curse my boots and shoes, but I will.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Jonas!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I will by—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Gives her purse) Here, here! How can you, child, be guilty of such immorality?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You should bribe me to be better.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Money, dear, should never be got by immoral means.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Then it will never be got at all.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: It would send us to a bad place.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ah! There will be a deal of the best company in that bad place. He that has money in his pocket is welcome every where. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I must tell you, Count, your behaviour astonishes me.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (With studied humility) Extremely sorry to have astonished your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Permit my son to visit your sister!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Your Ladyship's son did not ask my leave.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A youth of his fortune and connections!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: True: they are so great that, by your Ladyship's own order, he is never to be contradicted.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: How came he to know, Sir, you had a sister?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Very naturally, my Lady. I told him.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Oh you did!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I humbly hope the liberty was not unpardonable.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your hopes, Sir, are insolent!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I bow to the mildness of your Ladyship's reproof.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I supposed you a gentleman, or I should not have appointed you my son's tutor.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I hope my gentility will not disgrace that of your Ladyship's son.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p:
Your gentility, Sir! Your title of Count
might give an eclat as the tutor of my son: but of what real value is it?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Of very little, indeed, my Lady: it will not sell for a guinea.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And may be bought for a guinea where you procured it.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: "Happy country!"

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: But I will instantly put an end to such proceedings.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Let me humbly entreat your Ladyship not to be rash.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Rash, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I may well have been to blame, since doubts are entertained whether even your Ladyship have escaped immaculate!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I bend before your virtue, dangerous as the assaults are which I know it has endured!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You know, Sir! What is it you would insinuate?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Pardon me for having eyes and ears! Pardon their indiscretion when the gallant Highlander—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Sir!—The Highlander!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: At the masquerade, led the scarlet domino so tenderly to her chair, ordered it to Clargesstreet, followed muffled up—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I shall sink!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Shall I support your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Upon my word, upon my honor, Count—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh, my Lady! I will champion your honor.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You safely may, indeed, indeed!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
I will swear it! And who shall dare to
doubt? The only boon I ask is that my sister may be your gracious Ladyship's friend.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: But surely, Count, not my daughter?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: The Highlander, my Lady, was a remarkably handsome man!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (A knocking at the street door) I suppose this is Sir Job: what will he say?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh▪ your Ladyship and I possess the secret of making Sir Job say whatever we please.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Indeed! Was he too at the masquerade?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: He has been in masquerade a great part of his life.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You are an incomprehensible man, Count.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I shall find a time, my Lady, to make myself understood.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Here is a dressed up kind of country lady, that asks for her brother Harry.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: So not knowing her, I kept her back with my arm and—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Do not be impertinent, Sir. Show her up.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: (Going) Impertinent! This foreign Count takes upon him finely! [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: 'Tis my sister.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I will leave you alone.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Shall I not introduce her to your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Introduce?—Oh, certainly! Certainly. I'll return in a moment.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Bowing) I will remember your condescension.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: But my honor, Count.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am its guardian, and who shall dare impeach it? We are friends.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Most sincerely—I wish he was at the divle with all my heart. [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE XIII. Enter SERVANT and SUSAN.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: There is the Count, Madam.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee, oaf, it was brother Harry? Thou'll believe me another time, I hope.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I'll take good care, Madam.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Giving him money) Here.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Oh, oh! That alters the case. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What has been the matter?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, I curchied, and axt for you civilly enough: so a pulled and hauled me and made a combustibus.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You should behave like other ladies.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Harry, Harry, I have no right to any such title.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why not? Where is the difference between Susan Monrose and a lady?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why that be what I canno' find out. But what mun I say now thee hast brought me here? Mun I tell how I left father in dudgeon and runned away i' the broad wheeled waggon?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Not for your life.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p:
I shall never personate mysel': I shanno' know how to demander my carriage. I shall neither
know when to speak nor when to hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Fear nothing; make your remarks freely on all you have heard and seen since you came to London.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay then belemmy I shall have enough to talk on. But you have made me dress mysel' out in such tawdry flippets and flappets, so that I amsuch a mawx I can't abide mysel'.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: They will soon hang easy on you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: There han I sitten a long long hour while that outlandish barber, wi' his burning irons, wur a frowzling and a frizzling my top. And then, last of aw, a blinded me wi' dinging o' flour i' my face! No christian soul i' our town would know me! I do believe they'd shout and set the dogs at me!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Curse our town! Lady Ferment is coming. Up with your head, down with your shoulders, keep your arms back, talk away, and don't seem abashed.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Well, well, dunno' be cross, and I'll do my best.

div3.head: SCENE XV. Re-enter LADY FERMENT: they salute.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I congratulate you, madam, on your safe arrival in London.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, belemmy, we came safe and softly enough.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: How did you travel, madam?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, I came by the broad wheeled—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: By the Budworth coach, my Lady. But as your Ladyship hears my sister speaks the Cheshire dialect.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, belemmy, I dunno' much understand the Lunnun tongue.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You have been sometime in town?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Five weeks and two days.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Have you seen much of it?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, marry, I ha' seen more nur any modest body could for shame say.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Pray let me hear.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but an I dunno' take special care I know my tongue will soon get o' the wrong side o' my teeth.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Her Ladyship will allow for your country education, and I am sure will take nothing amiss.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Oh, by no means.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why then, i' my mind, as for your dressed up Lunnun moppets here, wi' their bare necks and painted faces! Marcy on's! They look as if—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: As if what?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I say nought.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You judge severely, Miss.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Miss! Every Molly now-a-days be a Miss! There be Miss Hop, and her papa the dancing-master: she be one of your high-flying tip-top Misses. Wi' her nose tossed i' the air and her trail sweeping the street. Then there be Miss Midge: her papa keeps a milk-cellar, and she be a more bedizened and a greater Miss nur t'other.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: But, you do not think them all alike?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No, truly: there be three sort o' folk i' Lunnun. There be they that ha' more money nur wit, they that ha' more wit nur money, and they that ha' noather t'on nor t'other.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And of which kind do you think me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, begging pardon for my audacity, I do suppose your Ladyship may ha' more money nur wit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aside) Well said, Susan!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Belike your Ladyship ha' been so busied i' spending your money you hanno' had time to learn much wit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aside) A shrewd gipsy!—What do you mean by wit, sister?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: That be a wise question! Your Lunnun fine Madams hanno' the wit to make a bed, dust a table, or darn a stocking. They canno' so much as ready their own hair, or fettle a cap; poor creatures! But are obligated to hire some needy body to do every varsal kind o' thing.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Then you think the needy have more wit than money?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, by my troth; and not much of oather.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aside) Oh, the malicious little hussey!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Well, child, have you executed my commissions?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: To the best of my ability, madam.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Haughtily) Madam?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I beg your Ladyship's pardon.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Oh! Remember to be more respectful.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Aurelia with great attention and kindness) Permit me to introduce my sister. (Aurelia and Susan salute and converse.)

div3.head: SCENE XVII. Enter OLIVER.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Now, Sir!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Bows. Then aside) I hoped Aurelia had been alone.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is your business?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: None: or any that your Ladyship shall please to give me.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: If you have none, Sir, your intrusion is unmannerly.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I beg pardon. (Aside to Aurelia) Will you walk in the Park presently?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Let me intreat you.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I have something essential to say.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: We have said too much already.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is all this whispering? Please, Sir, to go and see if Sir Job is come in.

div3.stage: [Exit Oliver intreating Aurelia by gesture, and she refusing.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Aurelia) I hope you will be good friends.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: (Giving her hand to Susan) With all my heart.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And wi' aw my heart and soul too. You are a farrantly body; and I like you: that I do. I like you.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: While you stay in town do me the favor, Miss Monrose, to accept apartments in my house. Aurelia, come with me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Are you going?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I must obey: but I will tell you a secret▪ My residence here will be short.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Behind) Are you coming, child?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You hear! [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Is not she a charming girl, sister?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, belemmy, she's quite a farrantly body; and I like her.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I knew you would. I must now tell you a little more of my plan.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Hold, Harry. If it be aught against conscience dunno' tell it me! Dunno'!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Pshaw! I must tell you, and you must act like a sister. Your aid is indispensible. Listen and guard what I shall relate as you would life. Aurelia is a rich heiress, cheated by two old harpies; who want her out of the way.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Marcy! Be that possable?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Literally true.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And dunno' she know it?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No, nor suspect it.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Marry but I'll run and tell her.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Holding her) Are you mad? 'Tis I must tell her.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but wo't thee, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Most certainly. But I must wait the proper moment. I love her, and am determined to secure her fortune and marry her.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay, but what an she wunno' ha' thee, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why should she refuse?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: She may have other likings.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I care not if she have.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Did no' thee mind how that young spark and she just now gave one another such looks?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I did. I read their meaning. They struck to my heart! But no matter: let me once have her in my power, let me secure her mine, and I warrant I will reconcile her to the disappointment.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: But dost thee truly and faithfully love her, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: From my soul.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And thee wo't use her like a mon?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: To her heart's desire.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why then setting that to be the case, Harry, I'll do my best for thee.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Seek her company, work yourself into her affections, and insinuate those good qualities which you know I possess.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I wish thee wur not a Count, Harry. Howsomdever, as far as conscience and honesty will go, I'll do my best. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
Why ay! Success, fortune, and Aurelia shall be mine! As for fame, give me but wealth, and that will come unasked. And yet my cursed querulous conscience takes part with my sister, and upbraids me for being an impostor. Absurd! Who are not impostors? Is any man the thing he seems? And, if feign we must, is it not better to feign something that the world respects, than something that it despises? The son of a curate, I have dashed into life, met variety of adventures, visited the Continent, and assumed the airs of a foreign Count. I have certainly disgraced myself; but the world does not think so. Who would shew his naked face when a mask is so pleasant, so profitable, and so easily put on? My father gave me education, Nature gave me desires, and I have
given myself a title. Why not? "If I am not a lord, it seems I ought to have been. I find no difficulty in being as extravagant as a lord, as proud as a lord, as idle as a lord, and as impudent as a lord. I could game like a lord, be duped like a lord, run in debt like a lord, and never pay, as naturally as if I had been born a lord. Let lords look to it, then, and reform. Let them be as superior to the poor in virtue as they are in power, and I will blush for being an impostor."

div3.head: SCENE I. The House of SIR JOB.

sp.speaker: SIR JOB.
sp.p: MY Lady is gone out, and we are safe enough here.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Safe enough? In danger enough, you mean! Were you mad or drunk to admit Aurelia Roland into your house?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What could I do?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: The orphan whom as executor you had robbed of her whole fortune.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I? It was you! You proposed the plan.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And you carried it into effect.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You had one half of her property.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: With good right! Fools catch the fish, wise men eat them. (Half-aside)

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: My wife brought her here in spite of my teeth.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Half-aside) The wife will rule when the husband's a fool. As for me, I have proved it to you again and again that I have been her best friend.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay, then, so have I.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Do you think, if she had known herself to be the heiress of a great fortune, that her behaviour would have been so modest?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh, no!

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Her manners so winning?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Her wit so keen? She may thank me, and me only, that she is not a vain, capricious, pert, prating, sprig of fashion.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh, her fortune has been no loss to her.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And a great gain to us.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: We knew how to make a good use of the money.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And to make a good use of money is to be honest.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes: we convinced each other, at the time, that we acted like honest men.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And now, at present, what would she do with her wealth, if she had it?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ay, and how could we do without it?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: She would know nothing of the price of stocks.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: She would never buy in at a proper time.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Buy in? She would always be selling out!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Instead of a good mortgage, she would be for the purchase of some rake helly husband—

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: That would call us to account.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Cut our throats.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Blow us upon 'Change.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: File bills in Chancery.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Deliver us over to the sword.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And the law.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: "And the church."

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And the devil.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: She must be got rid of.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I have a thought.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You have seen my son's tutor.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Yes: a keen fellow.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Has great influence with my wife.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Surely!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: A bold, dashing, impudent—one of your swaggering genteels.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Certain then to be a favourite with the ladies.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Secure him and the business is done. But do you know, from something he said this morning— (A noise heard without) Bless me! what's that?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Without) What are you doing, Sir?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Without) What is that to you?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: This way.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Sir Job and Mr. Taunton to an inner chamber.

div3.head: SCENE II. Enter JONAS and MONROSE.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why did you kick the servant's brushes and pail down stairs?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Because I like it. It's my humour. What business had you to let me go to that cursed hazard table?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I let! Did not I struggle, and hold you; and did not you drive a pin into my arm, and break from me?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Serve you right! Why did you tell me of such a pick-pocket place?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: We were passing, you read the word "Billiards," and I merely remarked it was a gaming-house.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Well! It's genteel. I like to game.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Then you must be content to lose.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: But I don't chuse to lose. I chuse to win. You should have taken care of that.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Yes, you. (Sulkily) My watch and all gone.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I could not stop you.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nya! Who says you could? Do you think I am to be stopped by you?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Jonas, dear, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Continuing sulky) Matter enough.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Bless me! Something has happened! What is it, Count?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am sorry to tell your Ladyship; but the truth must be known.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I am ready to sink! What?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I have lost my money.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: All! Yes; and enough too.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What a tremble you have put me in!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You always grumble to give me more. I have no watch now.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Is that gone too? You will ruin your poor mother.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Serve her right, for having ruined her poor son. So give me twenty shiners.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: My dear child, I have not them.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Get them, then.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I cannot! Indeed, Jonas, I cannot!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: But you must.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Where? Which way?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You know the way fast enough, without my telling.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I can prevail on Sir Job to do any thing, except part with his money.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What signifies your wrangling? You know very well I will have them.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear, you cannot.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Can't I? Then I'll go and throw myself into the Serpentine river.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Cruel boy!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: "As sure as you are living, I will.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Hear me!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I'll go.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: For heaven's sake stay!" You will be my death.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: It's a death of your own seeking.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Aside) The reproof is just.

div3.head: SCENE IV. Re-enter through the same door SIR JOB and MR. TAUNTON: the latter bows and passes on.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What, Count, have you and your pupil been walking?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, we are just returned. (Going)

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aside to Monrose) When my Lady is gone, I wish to speak with you.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I will attend you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Aside to Lady Ferment) I am going.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Terrified) Stay.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Will you tease the old one then for me?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You know, good for nothing, that I will.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Now, lapwing! Where's your brother Oliver?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Bowing) Can't tell, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Has he learnt better manners?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Don't know, Sir Job. If he would but have come with me, I would have taught him, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You hear, deary, what an obedient son you have got.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ah! The dog can be saucy enough.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Bowing) So I can, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! You can?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: It is not good manners to contradict my papa, Sir Job.
