sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: You don't know, sweet, how Jonas loves you.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No, that you don't, Sir Job: nor you never shall know.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What a happy man my dearest is in a son and a wife!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Very true, lovy. (Aside) I guess what she wants.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And I indeed am the happiest of women. Yet it is in my lambkin's power to make me happier still.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ay truly! (Aside) It won't do.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Will you consent?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Certainly I can refuse my turtle nothing. (Aside) I foresee a storm.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p:
And deary shall have his Cyprus wine,
his turtle soup, and any thing my hands can make him.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Thank you, lovy! Hem!—So you know nothing about Oliver?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: How should he, biddy? He is likely enough at some gaming table.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh! Five pounds to a crown at a gaming table! They are sad places—vile, damned, pickpocket places.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Zounds, you dog, how dare you swear?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And so, deary, now to make me completely happy.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes, my lambkin.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: If you could let me have just a little loose cash.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I have no loose cash, deary.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Nah, my sweet one, if it were only fifty pounds.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Hem! No more, jewel?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I perceive, Sir Job, you are determined not to make me happy.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aside) It is coming—I thought, lovy, that you were happy.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your evasions are vain, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aside) I wish Oliver was here—I must be going, lambkin.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your miserly propensities are contemptible. I'll be the slave of them no longer.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What is the matter, Sir? Why is her Ladyship so angry?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is that to you, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aside to Oliver) That's right! Stand by your father, you dog, or I'll disinherit you.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are in no need of support.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aside) You lie, sirrah, I am.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Lady Ferment is too loving, too tender a wife—

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: To need your interference, insolent Sir.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: There, Sir, I told you so.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: This usage shall not continue, Sir Job.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: No surely, my Lady. (Aside to Oliver) Don't mind what I say—Do you know, stripling, in whose presence you are? (Aside) Speak up.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Bowing) In the presence of Lady Ferment, Sir.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, Nol, you are a sly fellow.

sp.speaker: SIR. J.
sp.p: Do you forget that I have a right to knock you down when I please? Bombs and gunpowder, get out of my sight. (Aside) You may follow me—Begone, you vile—what shall I call you?—See to the settling of that account with Paywell and Co. Five hundred nineteen seven and six in our favour. Get about your business you, you, you Saracen Turk!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Following) Why, Sir Job, I say—

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I must have some money. The Serpentine river! Remember! I want pleasure, I want a wife, I want a thousand things. I will have some money. (Follows.)

div3.head: SCENE VII. (As they go off, MONROSE enters.)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What, is he gone?

div3.stage: (Enter SUSAN from the Door through which Sir Job and Mr. Taunton retired.)

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Greatly affected) Oh Harry! I am main glad I have found thee.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I have overheard such base villainy!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: How? Where?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why a bit a gone I was righting mysel' i' the little back room there; and so I had steckt the door o' th' inside; and there I heard a voice come into the next chamber and talk to somebody, and somebody gave answer in a gruff sound, and there, merciful goodness, forgive me! There did they argument over the making away with Miss Aurelia!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Making away with her!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: As I am a christian soul they did.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You mean getting her out of the way, I suppose.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, but that wur not aw, Harry, for they presently talked over thy name! They did, as I live and breathe! And mentioned of thee being consarned i' the plot! They did!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: If thee beest, Harry, if thee beest, Lord ha' mercy on thee!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Don't be frightened, fool.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but art thee, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Pshaw! No.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but art thee? I charge thee tell me verily and truly! Art thee?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Once more, no, no.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I doubt thee, Harry, I do mortally doubt thee! Lord, lord, where is she? What wull become of her?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Be pacified.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Thou art a good mon's son, Harry: think o' that. Dunno' disgrace thy parentage.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
(Sternly) Once more, girl, have done. I am as eager as you can be in Aurelia's defence. I
only determine to share the good I mean to confer. Hark! I hear Sir Job! Begone!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Going) Nay but bethink thee, Harry: say thy prayers and defy temptation. Do do, for the Lord Almighty's sake do! For I do mainly doubt the wicked one is often at thy elbow. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What an impassioned little fool it is!

div3.head: SCENE VIII. Enter SIR JOB and MR. TAUNTON.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Now we are alone, Count, I wish to say a word concerning this young woman: this Aurelia.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Alone, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Mr. Taunton is my friend.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, and confederate.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Confederate, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, confederate. (Aside) I must rouse their terrors—Are not you of opinion, gentlemen, that there is a deal of roguery in this world?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Why I—

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Perhaps there may.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Gross villany! Legal robbers!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Are are are there?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: That plunder the defenceless, strip the widow, and defraud the orphan: "yet assume to themselves the port of justice, and condemn wretches in rags by wholesale, ay, to the gallows, for petty three farthing thefts; while their own enormities are dressed out in authority, and law is made the guardian of great crimes and the merciless punisher of the unprotected."

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Are—Do do do you think so?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Taunton) Have you never known an instance?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Why I—I—Go with the crowd, if you would be kept in countenance.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Sir Job) Are you acquainted with no such person?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I—Really you nonplus me. I don't know what to say.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Say? Why say the truth. Say that it is a depraved, oppressive, despicable world; and that he who would live in it, if he would not be trodden under foot, must be like it. Come, let us acknowledge ourselves knaves.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Knaves?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, knaves; and glory in having the wit to be so. Then men will fear us, fawn on us, crouch to us, bear us on their shoulders while living, and raise altars to us when dead.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Hem!—Men must sell as markets go.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Really, Count, you you are very free. I—I—I mean severe.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You mistake, Sir. So compassionate am I that the secret you wot of hitherto rests with myself.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Does it?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: It does.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And shall it rest there?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Humph!—That—that is the point in debate. There are two old gentlemen of my acquaintance, and I, who resemble each other exceedingly.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Ay! In what?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: They love money; so do I. They wish to get a deal of it in a short way; so do I. They have relations whom they would be glad to provide for at other people's expence.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: And so would you?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: If they are prudent we may come to terms: if not—

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Sir, I don't understand all this.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No? Then you are very dull of apprehension.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Mischief hatch, mischief catch.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (To Taunton) Are you mad?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Serpents breed in still waters. Do evil and look for the like.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, well. Yonder comes a Lady who may quicken your faculties.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay but hark you, Count.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Since the gentleman does not know her, I will introduce him.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: For heaven's sake! Make your own terms! This way! Ask what you please.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well, provided Sir Gravity have recovered his understanding.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Hurrying Monrose off) I will be answerable. This way! This way!
sp.stage: [Exeunt Monrose and Sir Job: Taunton follows muttering.]

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Noisy fowlers catch no birds. Fools fish in troubled waters. [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE IX. Enter SUSAN at one Door, AURELIA at another.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (To herself) That be the same gruff voice! For sure they have been plotting together. Oh, Harry, Harry!— (Enter Aurelia)—Dear Miss, I be glad I ha' found you!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: And so am I. I am sorry to tell you, my sweet girl, that in all probability our acquaintance must soon end.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but why? I like you dearly! In faith and troth I do!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I believe it. Sympathy tells me you are sincere. But I must quit this house.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Mun you? I be glad o' that.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: True: You are a witness of my painful situation. What! Hire myself to be obliging? Take money to be a pretty behaved hypocrite? Bribed to be silent when I ought to speak, and to speak when I ought to be silent? Submit not only to insult but to deceit? Oh no! The terrors of poverty shall not compel me to that.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Do you know, I have a secret to tell you.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Ay! What is it?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, first of aw, brother has a liking to you.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A's mortaciously in love!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Surely you mistake.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No no, but I dunno'; a told me so himsel'.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay but surely, surely, brother be a likely mon?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I don't deny it.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A made a positive declaration that a likes you desperately.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: He is to blame. Heigho!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Mayhap your liking looks another way?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: My dear girl, I read the honest sincerity of your heart: I will therefore own there is but one man on earth—and for him I must never hope.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: So poor brother has no chance?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Oh no, my affections are unalterable.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A's well spoken! Well shaped! A has a mort o' learning! There be few can fellow him.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I grant you all; but my heart is gone.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why then, sin' it be positively so, aw's said and done. I know too sure that where one likes one likes: so do you take care o' yoursel'.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why I munno' tell! There be mischief hatching against you: but I munno' tell!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Against me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I abominate such wickedness, but I should break my heart if any harm were to behappen him.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why—No, I munno' tell!—But sin' you be for going, go. Lunnun be a wicked place! You dunno' know belike that you are what they caw a rich heir.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I rich.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: As I am a living soul you be. But do you make haste from this house; and be sure you let me know all about you! Be sure you do, for mayhap I may see you righted yet. So pray you now dunno' forget me. I shall never forget you: and so I may happen to see you righted. Good bye. Lord Almighty bless you! Good bye!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p:
What can this dear warm-hearted creature mean? She has raised a thousand tumultuous hopes and fears!—Whither can I go? To whom can I fly? Rich? An heiress? Plots against me? Is it my person or my life? I am strangely agitated! To take leave may be dangerous; and to depart secretly has the air of guilt. Fearful of others, suspecting myself, and abandoned to a world of which I am ignorant, my heart sinks at the prospect.
But, like a traveller in a desert, I must proceed or perish.

div3.head: SCENE XI. Enter SIR GUY, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Hark ye, young man, I ordered my carriage to take me up here: pray tell me when it comes.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: It is Sir Guy.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A devilish fine girl, upon my soul! Seems desirous to speak to me—Your servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Sir Guy, your servant.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You are acquainted with me, I find: may I take the freedom to ask who you are?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: A helpless woman without a friend, and about to stray I know not whither.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is it possible? Are you acquainted here?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I came to be the companion of Lady Ferment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, oh, you are my young friend Oliver's angel?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: No, no, Sir Guy, mere mortal.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And you find your situation irksome?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Not to be endured.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No wonder. What is your plan?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I have none. I am almost tempted to cast myself on the mercy of the first human being that will protect me.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Will you go home with me?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: That might be rash: yet from all I have heard you have the heart of a man.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You would not inflict misery for the pleasure of seeing it.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Don't be too sure.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You would neither despise nor add to the wretchedness you could not relieve.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Don't presume too far.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You would not contemn the forlorn, insult the feeble, nor trample on the distressed.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Zounds, Madam, do you know that I am a Baronet of seven thousand a year; and that I am but man? That I have raging desires, irritating sensations, headlong passions, and the means of gratifying them? Do you know all that?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I am glad that you do.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: That I cannot look on you, young beautiful and unprotected as you are, without feeling a mixture of emotions, some perhaps kind, some ridiculous, and some—Come, you shall go home with me.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Would you not despise me?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What, for trusting me: or believing me better than I am?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Indeed I have not an abject spirit.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What do you praise yourself for? Don't I tell you that your smiles have enchanted me? Come!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Well, I will accept your protection for a short time, but not an hour longer than I can find the means without servility of supplying my own few wants.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Heyday! Few? The few wants of a fine lady!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I have no pretensions to the character.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Hussey, hussey! By my soul I shall grow foolish. Your air, your shape, your looks, your
sentimental prattle are so many Syrens. Come, come along.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I am told I have dangerous enemies. Perhaps I am silly, but my fears have been alarmed. Suffer me to walk alone and unnoticed to the Square.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nay, but why?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I will give you my reasons in the carriage.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Well, well; any thing you wish. Should you ask me to marry, you are such a bewitching sorceress, curse me if I should not instantly comply. I am sure I should, so don't tempt me. Nor don't let my title, nor my seven thousand a year, tempt you. Sit at a proper distance, and turn your eyes t'other way, or, in spite of sixty-five, I shall be fascinated. [Exit.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I am happy once more to find you alone. I have been watching for it with tormenting anxiety.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: My heart is overcharged almost to bursting, and will have relief. Pardon the rashness with which I utter thoughts that I can no longer restrain.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Nay, pray desist.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I have not the power. The tide of passion hurries me headlong forward; and, were death to follow like a thunderbolt, I must fall lifeless at your feet with the words trembling on my lip—I love.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: I intreat you to forbear! Think how we are situated.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p:
Till now I knew not how heavy a curse
poverty and dependence can inflict. But I ask nothing, hope nothing, save the assurance that you do not love another—Is that denied me?—Your silence is distracting!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: You mistake. Be pacified. Pray leave me: we may be observed.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Oh, that I could communicate but a spark of the fire that devours me! Surely the strong sympathies I feel cannot all be false; and they tell me, rapturous delusion! that our souls pair instinctively. The mind that animates your beauteous form, and plays in your features, so harmonizes with my own that I seem conscious only of existence in your sight!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Once more forbear. Affected coyness I despise. If I appear to fly you, 'tis the severity of my fate to force me on that which perhaps rends my heart with as keen a pang as yours can feel.—Farewel! [Exit.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Alarmed) Farewel! Why farewel? Aurelia! [Exit following.

div3.head: SCENE I. The House of Mr. QUAKE.
div3.stage: Enter MONROSE and QUAKE, the latter alarmed.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: BF kind enough to stay there, Mr. Buffalo, with your assistants, and let nobody pass.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: What is the reason of this, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Be patient. You'll hear soon enough. I think, Mr. Quake, you have long been the attorney of Mr. Taunton?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Yes.—Yes, Sir—for thirty years.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Have transacted all his secret concerns?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I, Sir, I—I have done his business.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but his secret business?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON
sp.p: Can't you guess?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Did you never hear of one Admiral Roland?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: (Aside) Mercy!—No.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, you have.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why do you tremble?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Me? I am a little nervous. I am very ill. I am taken I don't know how.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No; you are not taken yet: they are only waiting for you.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: For me, Sir? What have I done?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Aided and abetted in robbing an orphan.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: As I hope for mercy I never robbed any body in my life; out of the honest way of my profession.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes, but the honest way of your profession won't save your neck, though you are a lawyer, unless Aurelia Roland and her fortune too be forthcoming.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I have not a farthing of her fortune, Sir.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Evasion is only waste of time. Aurelia Roland has been forced or lured away from the house of Sir Job.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: If she has, I have had no concern in it.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: But you know where she is, Goodman Quibble.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Who could tell you that, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: An intimate friend of yours, Sir; to whom you tell all your secrets. Mrs. Clack.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: (Aside) The devil take Mrs. Clack—I happened to be passing through the Square; and there, by accident—I saw Miss Roland step into the carriage with Sir Guy Taunton.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh, oh! With Sir Guy! It seems then, by accident, you do know her; and, by accident, you must remain in the custody of these gentlemen without: that I may be sure of your testimony when it is wanted.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I in custody, Sir? 'Tis a lawyer's business to put people in custody.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Or that or immediately go with me before a magistrate. Your character will then be blown past all remedy. If you comply and behave prudently, you may still perhaps be suffered to wear the mask of honesty.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you wrong me. I am honest.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: As honest as I could be, and do my duty.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Your duty!

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; my duty. I was Mr. Taunton's attorney. Had I betrayed my employer, nobody would ever have trusted me again. I was guilty of no more roguery than was necessary to keep a good character in the world.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, Old Logic! Thou say'st true. Thine is the current morality. That which is a man's interest is his duty. But come, decide: will you remain in custody for a short time or—?

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: In custody, Sir, since it must be so. Though indeed I have fingered no part of this lady's fortune.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No, Sir! Why then you have been both knave and fool.

sp.speaker: QUA.
sp.p: I fear as much.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You an attorney? Baw! You have not yet learned your rudiments. "What is a blockhead? A blockhead is a poor devil. Who are men of understanding? Every one who has five thousand a year. What is a knave? He that is hanged for cheating. And what an honest man? He that gets an estate by the same means. Who are most courted? Men of wit. And who are they? Those that give good dinners, make their friends drunk with the best wines, and then pick their pockets at hazard and faro. Who are most imitated? Men of fashion. And he is a man of the first fashion who associates with stable-boys in the morning, with opera-dancers and demireps after dinner, and with a Babel mixture of bullies, bubbles, and pickpockets from midnight to sunrise." [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE II. Changes to the house of SIR JOB, with a closet door.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p:
I can have no frolic till I get some money. Since we moved from the City, Sir Job keeps his loose cash, as he calls it, in that closet. If it were not for locks I could get at it; and then it would soon be loose enough. If I had got possession, I would make my mother give it me; and there is no harm in taking what is freely given. (Examines and finds
the door unlocked) Hay! Why the door is open! Who knows? Now for good luck! (Goes into the closet.)

div3.head: SCENE III. Enter LADY FERMENT and OLIVER.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Are you sure, Sir, you know nothing of her?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Only that she is gone.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: A very strange proceeding indeed! Leave my house without saying a word?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I intreated her to tell where she was going; but she refused.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: And how came you to know she was going?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I—I questioned her.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Your oglings, Sir, have been remarked; and I suspect you have been her escort.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Aside) Would that I had!—I have been on my father's business to receive this money.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you may leave the money with me.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam. I am accountable.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Impertinence! Have you seen the Count?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: No, my Lady.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Where can Jonas be gone? Wild thing! He is never a moment in a place. (Looks into an adjoining chamber).

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: My father has got the key of the closet, and I must keep this heavy bag in possession till he comes. (Looks round) The door is a-jar! Perhaps, knowing where I was gone, he left it open purposely. This is fortunate. (Goes into the closet.)

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: I can't see him. Where is this insolent youth gone with the money?

div3.stage: (Oliver returns, and shuts the door after him).

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: There, there. This spring lock will keep it safe enough.—When Sir Job comes in, my Lady, be kind enough to tell him I am waiting to pay the balance for which he sent me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: That is lucky, however. He cannot now pretend he has no cash. I must get some for this dear tormenting boy. [Exit.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Peeping out, having overheard) He has got some for himself. (Tossing the guineas) Here's pleasure! Here's frolic! Here's watches, and rings, and ribbands for Susan! Oh lord! Oh lord! I was snug in the corner: Oliver could not see me. Ha, ha, ha! I have filled up the bag with counters. Hold! I must shut the door; and then this spring lock will make all safe. Your spring lock is a kind of politician's puzzle: he that is in can easily get out; but he that is out must procure a key. (Shaking the guineas) Here they are! Where shall I find Susan? Here's music! Here they are! [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE V. Enter SIR JOB, OLIVER, and LADY FERMENT.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: There is a bill below for five hundred pounds, waiting payment: have you been where I ordered you?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aside) It is lucky this bill is come for payment: else, knowing I had money in the house, I should have had no peace with my Lady.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: (Presenting bills) Here are four hundred and fifteen bank; and a hundred guineas in that closet.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Go and fetch them.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: You have the key, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Then how did you get in?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: The door was open.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Oh, I remember. (Gives the key) I had no cash, as I told you, deary; so, ha, ha, ha! I was not afraid of being robbed. (Oliver returns with the bag. Sir J. feeling) What is here, Sir? This neither weighs nor feels like guineas.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I counted and put them in myself.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Indeed! Then my touch deceives me. (Takes out a handful) Heyday! Why, what the devil are these?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Is this witchcraft?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You counted them yourself!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I am thunder-struck!

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: (Aside) Mercy! If this should be a trick of Jonas'!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Sir Job, my Lady, if the tongue of man be capable of truth, I left this bag, or one like it, with a hundred guineas in that closet not twenty minutes ago. Your Ladyship saw me go in.

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: (Without) Leave off!

sp.speaker: JONAS.
sp.p: (Without) I must kiss you!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Entering) I wunno' be poo'd and hawd a this'n!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: What uproar is this?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Aside) The sport is spoiled: I hoped there was nobody here.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (To Oliver) How dare you stay in this house, you vile—I have no name bad enough for you. Get out of my doors!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What is the matter, Nol?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I am charged with fraud, with robbery, brother.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Whoo! (Lady Ferment reprimands Jonas by gestures)

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I just now left a bag with a hundred guineas in that closet, which has been stolen, and I am to be turned adrift like a felon.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Are you?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; he is!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Curse me if he shall. Nol is no thief.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: How do you know, sirrah?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nol is no thief, I say.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Then who stole my hundred guineas?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why, look you—If it was stealing, I stole them.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: And where are they, dog?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Listen! Hark!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Jonas jingles them in his pocket, and slips away when Sir Job endeavours to seize him) You impudent, confounded whelp!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nol! Will you have a few? I know you are at short commons.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Jonas, though this is a bad trick, I am glad to find you have an honest and a generous heart. Yet consider the consequences of this thoughtless conduct. Think that a brother, whom you love, has been accused of theft; and in danger of suffering all the disgrace which such a vice well deserves.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Oliver, Sir Job, and Lady Ferment: the two latter reprimanding Jonas by gesture.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I believe it was not quite right, but I have no time just now to be sorrowful—Harkye, Susan.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What sayn you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Look! What a sweet pretty robin redbreast!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (After looking) Where?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Look! Look! Can't you see it? (Locks the door slily)

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Shewing the key) In its cage.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Aside) Oh the cunning sly tooad!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I have her now!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: How shall I get away? A's a desperate wicked one!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Now we are fairly alone, I have a secret to tell you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Ay marry! What be that?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why that I am confoundedly in love.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: In love be you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh lord! Yes.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why, an you be got in, the best way will be to get out again.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: That's just my intention, and you must help me.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Aside) What i'the name of goodness shall I do?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: But first tell me, what is your opinion of me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Of you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ay; what do you think of me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: By the mackins, I think you bin a queerish kind of a youth!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You do?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, by the mass do I!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why then there is a pair of us. But, queer as I am, could you like me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Like you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Ay: love me?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, belemmy. (Jonas approaches and she pushes him back) Best when furthest off.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Nah now—I want a wife, and I like you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Aside) An I dunno' coax'n, I shall ne'er get away. I wish I had the key.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Am I to your taste?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I canno' tell. In our town, it's taste and try. We always bite afore we buy.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Going to kiss her) Oh! with all my heart!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, nay: hold a blow! Pray now did you ever play at kisses and commands?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No: but I should like to play at them exceedingly.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Well then, I'll learn you how.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh lord, do! That is the very game I want to be at! I would fain both kiss and command.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: It's a this'n. You be to kiss when I command.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: That I will with all my soul!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And I be to kiss when you command.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh lord! Better and better! Come, let us begin.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but you be in too much a haste. First we are to pay our forfeits: so then the game begins.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Come then pay away! Oh, it will be rare sport! Here; here. Take the guineas first.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No. I wunno' foul my fingers wi' they.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why I got them purposely for you!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I tell you, I wunno' come near them.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p:
Well, well, here's my handkerchief, and my pocket-book, and my pencil-case, and my
knife—No; I'll not give my knife: that cuts love.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Is that aw? Feel i'your coat pocket; for, you know, the more forfeits—

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, ay! The more kisses! Here! Take my gloves: two, mind, two: and the key, and—stay, stay! I'll give you my knee-buckles, and my shoe-buckles, and—

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Hold a bit. I ha' enow now. So you be to hold your hat for mine.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Here it is. Make haste!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Pretending to feel in her pockets) By the mackins, i'this dowdy dress, I ha' got welly nought about me—Hold—In our town, the lasses sometimes gi' the lads their mittens, and their neckkerchiefs, and— (Bashfulness) And their garters.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Do they? Let me have them!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: But then the lads awways turn about, you know, wi' their▪ faces t'other way.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Turning) What, so?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea, a that'n: but go a bit a gait.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: A gait! What's that?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: More further off.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: So?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Retreating to the door) Nigher to the wall—Nigher yet—Now don't you turn!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What, not one peep?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Oh, no! for an you do the game's over!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Well, make haste.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Dunno' you look. Stand stock still. I ha' welly done. (Having unlocked the door and gone out, she peeps in) You may turn about, now.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Hay! What! Are these your tricks?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Look! Look! What a pretty robin redbreast there be! (Bangs-to the door.)

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh you confounded little jade, but I shall catch you! Well, it is plaguy tantalizing when one is in such a hurry to be married, to be balked so often. Oh that I had a chaise and eight now at the door, and this dear little gipsy in my arms! She would struggle: so should I. "Pray, Mr. Jonas, let me go!" I can't, my love! "Consider my blushes!" Consider my impatience! "Nay but duty, decency!" Are both drabs; a queer pair of prudes; two frumpish freakish old-fashioned tabbies; all polite people now are ashamed of their company. So let us leave them to their favourite friends, old maids cabal and a brandy bottle, and hey for Scotland, you sweet charming— (Going)

div3.head: SCENE IX. Enter MONROSE, bringing in SUSAN by the wrist.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Again.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Leave us, Sir.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Leave you, Sir?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yes; I can't waste time in trifling, and am in no humour for compliments. Leave us.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: You might be in a humour for good manners, methinks. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: The beest woundy crabbed, Harry.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
What is the reason, madam, that you thus counteract me in my fairest prospects, and my dearest hopes? How dare you traverse me at the
very moment when misery or happiness supreme depends on the event? Why did you alarm Aurelia, and advise her to fly?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: That my conscience mought no' fly i' my face, Harry, as thine will do.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Your conscience! Was it your conscience that told you to betray your brother?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Yea belemmy wur it. But I would no' give ear to my conscience, so I said nought that could harm a hair o' thy head.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: How! Did not you tell me yourself, just as we were interrupted, that you had betrayed me to her?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No, by my troth did not I. I only towd thee how I towd she how desperately thee said thee wur in love. So she said she wur mortal sorry for it: for why? She had fixed her liking elsewhere.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Ay, ay: on this Oliver. Damned fortune! I am her saviour. She is mine in equity, and mine she shall be.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Then what does thee mean to do, Harry?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Secure her, win her, possess her. Observe what I say, and for your life dare not this time to swerve one tittle from what I prescribe. Send for a coach, return to your lodging, and be ready to receive her. She will be there within an hour.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: That canno' be, Harry. I be mortal sure she wunno' come of her own good will.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Good-will or ill-will, come she shall; and there I tell you she will be. Prepare, therefore, to aid me, as I order you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Thee may'st order what the wo't, Harry; but I'll be consarned i' no such deformity.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
Damnation! Am I to be eternally
thwarted thus by a mere puppet! Once more, girl, listen and obey.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Thee may'st fell me at thy feet, thee may'st kill me, an thee wo't, Harry; but I wunno'. I have said it, and I wunno'.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Hell and— (Snatches out his watch, sees the hour, and hastily crosses) Hark you, I know not how far your infernal obstinacy may lead you▪ You have already injured me deeply; but, should you venture to whisper one more treacherous word, tremble at my vengeance. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Marcy keep me, what a wicked passion a be in! A'll come to no good; and my heart wull brust. What shall I do? I have no christian soul to break my mind to. A said a would bring poor Miss Aurelia to my lodging. What if I do go and some how watch? Who knows but I mought save her from ruination, and betray him from a mort o' mischief? I munno' tell ought, for then belike a wull be taken up; and what mought betide, oh Lord! Oh Lord! Supposing him before the justice!—I'll do't—I wull—I'll say my prayers and ventur, I'm detarmint. (Going)

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Stop! Stop a moment!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Angrily) Keep a gait, then! Do.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: My sweet girl, there is something the matter with you. I know there is, so don't deny it. Here I am, and if I can do you any service, curse me but I shall jump out of my skin for joy.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: No, no, I ha' no soul on earth to open my bosom to.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: What then you dare not trust me? Damn it, I did not think you had thought so ill of me as that!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: An any harm were to befaw him (Weeping bitterly) I should never more be i' my right mind. I love him from my very heart's core. A's my only brother. A has tricks, but a's a fine mon. There be few like him; an if a should no' die in his bed, Lord ha' marcy upon me! I should go raving melancholy.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Dry your eyes. He shall not die at all. We'll save him. I'll manage the matter.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Why wull you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I hate listeners, and yet I listened and heard all.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Did you, for sure?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: And will you be true and faithfoo'?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: If I am not hate me. You have not betrayed his secrets, mind: you have told nothing. I'll save him.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Wull you?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: An you do, I shall love you to the longest breath I draw.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I hope so, for I shall love you longer▪ You are the sweetest, bewitching—

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, but bethink you. Shall I go to the lodging house?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Do. It may prevent mischief.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Well, and how then?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Oh, I have it! Brother Nol and old gruff Sir Guy.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but that will betray Harry!

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Not a bit. They are noble souls! Sound hearts! They would not hurt man, woman, or child. Do you make haste. I must fly. I shall accomplish it; and then, oh Lord, oh Lord! I shall be a happy dog! [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A's a greadly lad! A's a farrantly lad! And I be welly overcome to think a has so kind a heart! An a make his words good, I do believe I shall love him ten thousand times better nur I do brother Harry! [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE I. The Lodgings of SUSAN. Loud knocking at the Street Door.
div3.stage: Enter SUSAN hastily and in much alarm.

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: SO, so! A be come at long length. (Knocking again) A's in a wicked haste—There—the door opens—Now for it! What wull be the upshot on't?—Goodness, how dizzy I be!—Dear, dear, what be come to me!—I am taken all over as thof I had an ague fit—I mun bear up—I hear him—A be coming—Marcy deliver me! (Retires.)

div3.head: SCENE II. (Enter MONROSE and AURELIA, preceded by a Female Servant with Candles, which she places on the Table and departs.)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Let me intreat you to quiet your alarms, you are safe.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Safe! Insulting mockery! Why have I been forced here? What is your purpose?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Kind as your heart could wish.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Are falsehood, artifice, and outrage kind?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Blame the depravity which not merely justifies but renders them unavoidable.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Away! 'Tis the vulgar cant of common place vice.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You are yourself the victim of this depravity.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I feel I am. I find myself ensnared, unprotected, and in your power. But if you hope to bend me to dishonest purposes, I smile at your impotence.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I am no enemy, but a determined and active friend.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: A friend!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I conjure you to conquer for a moment your suspicions and fears. Grant me an attentive hearing.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Well, Sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You are an injured orphan. The heiress to great wealth, of which you have been wickedly deprived. I am blessed in being your deliverer. Pardon me for boasting, but I glory that by my efforts the iniquity has been discovered.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: If that were true, what need was there for the compulsion you have practised?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: How shall I answer? How expiate a fault that perhaps is unpardonable? Yet surely my crime itself will plead some abatement in my favour! 'Tis vain in me to falter—I love.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Love!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
Ay, to distraction!—Why do you regard me with that sovereign disdain? My life, faculties, and soul, shall exhaust themselves to yield you pleasure. I petition for that which a weak or
presumptuous man would claim as a due, but which I will hoard in my heart as the precious boon of the divinity whom I adore.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: The blandishment of words can neither disguise nor palliate unworthy actions. Had your proceedings been open and direct, no taint of suspicion would have glanced on the professions you make, or the benefits which you say you have the power to confer, and I should have felt a bitter pang in refusal. But, were my affections free, nay, had they before been devotedly yours, the deceit you have employed, and the planned artifice of which I find you capable, would have placed an eternal barrier between us.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: If you knew the firm purpose of my soul to make you happy— (Susan watching)

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Pleading is vain.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Seizing her hand, but falling on his knee) I would fain prevail by soft and gentle means.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Do you threaten?

div3.stage: (Susan still approaching, but with great trepidation)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: When you shall find how true how tender my heart can be, you will hereafter pardon the presumption of this moment. (Rising) Should I lose it, you and happiness were lost for ever. (Clasping her.)

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Stand off!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: My fate— (Sees his sister, and stamps.) How now!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Falling on her knees before him with her hands clasped) Harry!—Kill me—Put me out o' the world.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Violently) Get up.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I canno'.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Leave the room.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: I munno'. (Monrose seizes her by the arm, and

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Hold, or turn upon me. (They collar each other.)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Boy!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Forbear—

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: No such boy, you find. I am not so easily to be shaken off. I am of the bull-dog breed. Damme I would muzzle any mad animal that should attempt to toss my sweet Susan. (Monrose walks up the stage in violent perturbation.)

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Aurelia, are you safe?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Perfectly. Thanks to my kind and faithful friend here. (To Susan.)

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: The chariot of Sir Guy is below: Do you, my brother, and Miss Monrose, return to my father's. Sir Guy is there. I must endeavour to bring this violent man.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Nay but will not that be dangerous?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Fear nothing. I am calm. I am prepared; and you know my principles. His presence is absolutely necessary.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Earnestly) Surely, surely, you dunno' mean to harm brother Harry?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Harm him? No!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: A's a good mon's son, and I hope a'll be a good mon himsel'. I do hope and trust a wull. [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE IV. OLIVER following to the door, and MONROSE advancing lays hold of his arm.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: A word with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Willingly. Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: You and I it seems are rivals. Time is precious, and I shall be brief. Yield your pretensions to Aurelia.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: By what right, Sir, do you make this abrupt and peremptory demand?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: By the right that every man has to guard his own happiness.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: And that right justifies my refusal.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Sir, I am an angry man; an injured man; a determined man. My soul is on the stretch: my spirits are flaming. Beware of me!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: I am aware of you.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: I have risked my all. This is the crisis of my fate; and either comply, or one of us shall never depart alive.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Your threats are impotent.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Then my deeds shall be decisive. (Produces pistols) Take this.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: For what purpose?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: A gentleman need not ask.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Pshaw! Jargon!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: No delay! Aurelia is yours or mine.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Are you an assassin?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Do assassins furnish their enemy with weapons?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: If murder must be committed, the glory must be all your own: for never shall this arm be levelled at the life of man.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Damnation! Coward! Fire!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Fire you, madman!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Hell!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p:
Think you I am to be bullied into what you call courage? If you are so wound up to murder, begin! Here is your mark! Take your level! A shot through the heart, or a bullet through the
brain. Then vaunt of your dexterity; and again reiterate your epithet, gentleman.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Gnashing) To be thus baffled!

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Abandon your purpose, or dispatch: for not all the arguments of hell, nor all its fiends, shall drive me to shed the blood of human being.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: To be thus tamed! Oh! Idiot! I the master of accident? Fool! Fool! I am the very slave of prejudice.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: What! Is an antipathy to crime, prejudice?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (Peremptorily) Leave me, Sir—to my own contempt. I am what I despise, a braggart.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Thank heaven! There are many braggarts in vice. You are a better man than you supposed. 'Tis no uncommon character. Remember then that Aurelia requires your aid.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Peace! I will be no man's automaton: will hear no pleadings. I am the lord of my own actions, and will be self-moved.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: You have a loftiness of soul which I love: pursue its dictates.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (After a pause) It shall be so! Monrose shall yet rise on the necks of wretches that hope ere this to trample him in the dust. Follow and behold! [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE V. The House of SIR JOB.
div3.stage: Enter SIR GUY and MR. TAUNTON.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, snail, how came Aurelia to be creeping across fields with you at that time of night?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I—I—I don't know how it came.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why did you not fight, and defend her?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I fight, indeed! Talk of guns, but don't go near them.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
You say it was within a hundred yards of
a house. Why did not you bawl for help? Owls can hoot; and geese can cackle.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Really you cross question one like an Old Bailey barrister!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And, really, you answer like an Old Bailey witness.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I only know that I took Aurelia out to walk; and that some ruffians rushed from behind a hedge, and carried her off.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It's a damned strange story; and a strange affair too!

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I hope you don't suspect me, brother?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why should you suppose I suspect you?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Now, Sampson, is there any news of them yet? Are they come back? Are they safe?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I hear nothing.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You seem to care nothing.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aside) I wish I had no cause.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And pray how do you mean to provide for Oliver?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I? Which way must I provide?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) This fellow will tempt me to cut his throat.—Marry him.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Why I have thought of that. A wife's fortune might do the business. But he—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Look at me—To a wife without a fortune.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Suspecting) Hay? What?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: How, Sir Guy?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To the richest, poorest woman in England!

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Who is that, brother?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Aurelia Roland, Balaam.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Alarmed) Why, brother?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (In the same tone) Sir Guy!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir Job! Sir Jack a lent! What the devil are you both petrified?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: How is she rich?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: In beauty, in mind, in virtue.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Aside) Oh! Is that all?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: They can't pay for a penny loaf.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: She is friendless, fatherless, portionless.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You have told one, two, three—hem!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Who is her friend?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I am. (Both alarmed)

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Who is her father?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: Who is her banker?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: You talk in the clouds. You are not her father.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Who made you a judge? What do you know about fathers? He is a father that has a father's affection, and will perform a father's duties.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay but—Will you, Sir Guy?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Yes I will, Sir Goose!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aside to Mr. Taunton) What shall we do? We shall be blown.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (To Sir Job) I told you what would come of it. Feast with fools, and fare as they do.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Nay but what shall we do?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I don't know. (Knocking heard, Sir Guy crosses to the door)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It is she! Here she comes!

div3.head: SCENE VII. Enter AURELIA, SUSAN, and JONAS.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Oh, Sir Guy!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My dear girl, here you are once more safe and free.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Taking Susan's hand) Yes, and here is her deliverer.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay, indeed!

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, this dear, courageous, affectionate girl is the saviour of us all. While my heart beats, she shall have a warm place in it.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: She will have a warm place in other people's hearts as well as yours.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh ho!

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: But are you sure though, are you deadly sure that nobody will bring brother Harry to shame?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Most certain. (Aside) And yet I wish Oliver and he were returned.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: It is time, I see, for me to be moving.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What, curlew, do you forebode a storm?

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I can't tell. High winds ruin a fair harvest.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Stay where you are, I tell you.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: I can't stay, and I won't stay.

div3.head: SCENE VIII. Enter OLIVER and MONROSE.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Yet stay you must, Sir. Your presence is necessary in court. Here am I a bold faced knave that appear without a summons, and call on you as one of my accusers. Sir Job shall be another.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (Aside) I wish I was any where but in this house.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: "'Tis no uncommon case for the least criminal to be condemned by his accomplices."

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: (Aside to Monrose) Are you mad? Why did you come here?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p:
(Aloud) Why not come here, Sir? I ask not you to blush for any crime of mine. Which of you sober seniors will sit as my judge? (Turning to Sir Guy) Your pardon, Sir, my words do not
glance at you. Be my actions what they will, I can distinguish, ay, and can reverence virtue.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Go on: No apologies, I am no better than I should be.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Well then, here I stand, and put myself upon my country. "What is my crime? A sovereign contempt for the selfishness to which genius and virtue are the daily sacrifice; and, since honesty could procure me neither favor nor fortune, a resolution to be no longer its dupe.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Systematic vice of all others is the most dangerous."

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Fellows like me, thrown on the pavement, and wanting the varnish of gold and hypocrisy, give us but a bad name, and any idiot can trace halters in every feature. But turn here! Behold these grey beards! How smooth is all without! How sanctified is all within! How sedate is every hair and wrinkle! Have sires like these their secret sins? Can they plunder the orphan, persecute the innocent, and disturb the ashes of the dead until they rise and cry for vengeance?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: "Have patience.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Proceed then! Arraign me at your bar, class me with villains, load me with opprobrium and punishment; then contrast my actions, my character, my crimes, with these honest, these magisterial men; and, having so done, raise the whip, strike, and applaud the wisdom of your laws, and the justice of your decisions.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is this reality?"

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Did I seek support in villany by example, think you I should want precedents? (Taking Sir Job and Mr. Taunton each by the hand) Stand forth, reverend iniquity! Here are we three!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It is most strange! (Knocking hard at the street door) What more?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: What is the meaning of all this, Mr. Taunton? Here is the parlour full of Bow-street runners, keeping your attorney in custody.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: (In great terror) Mr. Quake?

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: It's all over. (Sir Job and Mr. Taunton are endeavouring to retire)

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nay, nay, you must not flinch. Stand to it, and if you have nerves string them! Behold this lady. (Pointing to Aurelia) Look at the lovely daughter of your generous mutual and confiding friend! Dying, he bequeathed the expiring mother and the helpless infant, not to your humanity but your justice. Where is the wealth he deposited in trust? Full fifty thousand pounds, with the accumulating stock of twenty years! Answer! Has it been husbanded well? Produce the statement.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Good heavens!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Left to that charity which ever finds some gentle breast to hide in, here she stands, if hearts you had, with wrong enough to wring those hearts in pangs unutterable.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Are these things possible?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: My witnesses are ready. Let him that dare deny the charge.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mr. Taunton! Have you no answer? (Short pause.)

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Nor you, Sir Job? (He turns away.)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My blood runs cold! This man my brother?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Their silence is their assent.

sp.speaker: MR. T.
sp.p: The Lady shall have her due. The tree of knavery bears bitter fruit. [Exit.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: Brother is a brave mon! I knew a wur! I knew a had it about him!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I am choaked! I could not say a word to the fellow.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (To Sir Job) Well, Sir, will you follow your leader's example?

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Ay, ay; I have followed it a little too often!

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: What, ashamed of knavery at these years!

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: I shall never shew my face in the City.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: "Ha, ha, ha! The City? Why, man, you and I are petty knaves! Console yourself: crimes of a much deeper dye no longer are a nine days wonder. Some friendly scandal, with `Bless me, who would have thought it!' and a little gross abuse, which you'll not hear, is the utmost penalty. Meanwhile bows, salutations, and grinning courtesy will be current as ever. 'Tis only the needy villain that is shunned."

sp.speaker: SIR J.
sp.p: Heigho! It is bad I find to do wrong: but it is worse to be found out. [Exit.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Your reproof is severe.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Why, ay. I am still a disciple of the world and its maxims; I can persecute vice in others and practise it myself like any potent Don in Christendom.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis strange, Sir, that a fellow of your soul should class himself with knaves.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Nothing is strange. Man is all a contradiction. I thought myself an adept, I find myself a tyro. He that would succeed in knavery, must be wholly knave. I have compunctions and sympathies which a man must either shake off or go hide in honest obscurity.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: "Are talents and genius, then, no recommendation?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Talents and genius are the admiration of a day: so is a calf with two heads, or any other monster."

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (With affectionate timidity) Brother Harry—Wull thee forgi' me?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Forgive thee, girl! My soul adores thy kind and honest nature.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (In tears) I love thee, Harry! I love thee!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Catching her feelings) And damme but so do I!—I love you all.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Oh, how blessed is this moment! How grateful to my heart is the little power which wealth can give! (To Susan) My everlasting friend. (To Monrose and Sir Guy) And you my saviour, you my protector.

sp.speaker: OL.
sp.p: Not a word for me?

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: Will not a look suffice?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: (With dejection) You are a happy man, Sir.

sp.speaker: AUR.
sp.p: (To Monrose) You have proved the dignity of your mind. You have gained friends that will never forsake you.

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (To Aurelia) The Goodness bless you! I said from the first I loved you dearly.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: I find I am quite left out among you! (To Susan) Surely you don't forget your promise?

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: What wur that?

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: (Imitating Susan) "I shall love you to the latest breath I draw."

sp.speaker: SUS.
sp.p: (Abashed) No, no, I hanno' forgotten.

sp.speaker: JON.
sp.p: Why then, my Lady—You know what▪

sp.speaker: LA. F.
sp.p: Well, but, my dear Jonas—

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.p: Oh, her Ladyship will freely consent, and will be happy to dance a reel at your wedding.—Well, I have hitherto lived, and fear I shall die wondering at the enormous vices, and the splendid virtues, which mingle and form the history of that motley creature man.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And what is it that will correct his errors? It is the virtue that has been exercised to day. It is purity of intention in some, benevolence of heart in others, and that kind, forgiving, and indulgent spirit, which ought to inhabit every human bosom. [Exeunt Onmes.
